Title: Detecting price and search discrimination on the internet
Summary: The first study to demonstrate price discrimination online, finding evidence of price discrimination depending on web history and geographic location.

Title: Crowd-assisted search for price discrimination in E-commerce: First results
Summary: Implements and demonstrates a method for evaluating price discrimination on over 600 websites. Results show how that a number of factors affect personalized prices, especially location and login status.

Title: Discrimination in Online Ad Delivery
Algorithm: Search engine results page - full page
Summary: An early look at the risks of targeted advertising, this paper studies searches for 2,184 full names on Google and Reuters, and studied differences between black-identifying and white-identifying names. Results showed that "ads for public records on a person appeared more often for those with black-associated names."

Title: Google search: Hyper-visibility as a means of rendering black women and girls invisible
Algorithm: Search engine results page - full page
Summary: A case study audit that exposes gender and racial discrimination in Google search results, namely toward black women.

Title: Measuring Price Discrimination and Steering on E-commerce Web Sites
Summary: Corroborates early findings of price discrimination, focusing on travel websites and general retail websites. They also investigate five features which could discrimination (browser, OS, account log-in, click history, and purchase history), identifying several retailers that appear to change prices based on these features.

Title: Unequal Representation and Gender Stereotypes in Image Search Results for Occupations
Algorithm: Search engine results page - full page
Summary: This audit of Google search results showed that the system exaggerated stereotypes and underrepresented women. Their baselines came from the bureau of labor statistics, from which they also selected occupations to use as search terms.

Title: An Empirical Analysis of Algorithmic Pricing on Amazon Marketplace
Summary: Scraped prices for best-selling items on Amazon, finding over 500 sellers using some form of dynamic algorithmic pricing. They found that these sellers were more often to receive feedback and win the "Buy Box."

Title: Bias in Online freelance marketplaces: Evidence from TaskRabbit and Fiverr
Old-Behavior:
Gender bias
Racial bias
Intersectional bias
Geographic bias
Summary: While most of this study pertains to bias in the reviews, one section finds systematic bias on TaskRabbit's search algorithm: workers perceived to be White rank lower than workers perceived to be Asian, but higher than workers perceived to be Black. Also, being perceived as female correlated with lower ranks for White workers, but higher ranks for Black and Asian workers.

Title: Tracking gendered streams
Summary: Using 288 "sock puppet" Spotify users, this audit found that recommendations were similar between registered male and registered female users. However, the overall gender ratio of recommended musicians was highly skewed toward male artists: approximately 8 out of 10 recommended artists were identified as male.

Title: An Empirical Study on Online Price Differentiation
Summary: Designs and implements a price scanning system to examine the effect of browser fingerprints on price discrimination. While the results show location-based price differentiation, system fingerprints have less of an effect.

Title: Gender Shades: Intersectional Accuracy Disparities in Commercial Gender Classification
Summary: A seminal study that showed disparities in facial analysis tasks with respect to skin tone. The first study (among those reviewed) that explored intersectional disparities (i.e. light-skinned male vs. dark-skinned female) rather than single-class disparities (i.e. male vs. female).

Title: Investigating the impact of gender on rank in resume search engines
Summary: A large-scale scrape of job queries showed that individual candidates with higher probability of being masculine rank higher in search results, controlling for factors such as skills, education level, experience, and more. Measurement of group fairness also exposes gender discrimination, with women being under-represented in search results for many jobs.

Title: Actionable auditing: Investigating the impact of publicly naming biased performance results of commercial AI products
Old-Behavior:
Gender bias
Racial bias
Intersectional bias
Summary: A follow-up to the original gender shades study, this paper presents a targeted audit of facial analysis models from Amazon and Kairos, and discusses how several companies responded.

Title: Algorithmic bias? An empirical study of apparent gender-based discrimination in the display of stem career ads
Summary: Deploying a gender-neutral advertisement on Facebook, the study finds that men saw more impressions than women, younger women saw it less often than younger men, and yet women were more likely to click the ads. In robustness checks for clicking behavior, labor market conditions, and competitive spillovers, the authors find that women are often more expensive to advertise to. They replicated their main findings on Google Adwords, Instagram, and Twitter.

Title: Does Object Recognition Work for Everyone?
Summary: This short paper shows that object recognition systems perform worse on objects from lower income households, partly due to appearance differences (ex. bottled dish soap vs. bar dish soap) and partly due to context differences (ex. toothbrush in a bathroom vs. toothbrush in other rooms).

Title: Fairness in proprietary image tagging algorithms: A cross-platform audit on people images
Organization:
Amazon
Google
IBM
Microsoft
Imagga
Clarifai
Summary: Applies a cross-platform audit to test image tagging systems using the Chicago Face Database, identifying several systems that perform worse on people with dark skin and females.

Title: Fairness-aware ranking in search & recommendation systems with application to linkedin talent search
Summary: This study proactively audits fairness metrics for a talent search recommender on LinkedIn. In both simulations and A/B experiments, they find their recommender produces gender-representative results in 95% of all searches, almost a 3X improvement over the original recommender.

Title: Social B(eye)as: Human and machine descriptions of people images
Summary: This is a sibling study to "Fairness in proprietary image tagging," adding a comparison between the tagging algorithms and tags from crowdworkers. Preliminary findings show that crowdorker tags exhibit more diverse vocabulary, for example, the six APIs studied have no tags considered "Inconclusive, Inflammatory, or Nonbinary." The authors make the resulting "Social B(eye)as" dataset publicly available for research.

Title: Why machine learning may lead to unfairness: Evidence from risk assessment for juvenile justice in Catalonia
Summary: This study proactively audits machine learning algorithms as potential replacements for a risk assessment tool called the Structured Assessment of Violence Risk in Youth (SAVRY). They find that

Title: Auditing Race and Gender Discrimination in Online Housing Market
The Risk of Racial Bias in Hate Speech Detection
Summary: This study shows how hate speech detection systems risk many unintended negative impacts. Specifically, "tweets by self-identified African Americans are up to two times more likely to be labelled as offensive compared to others."

Title: Measuring Personalization of Web Search
Summary: One of the first search engine audits, this study showed that personalization on Google search does not substantiate "filter bubble" effects, as only 11.7% of results are personalized, on average.

Title: Location, Location, Location: The Impact of Geolocation on Web Search Personalization
Summary: This study found the main source of personalization on Google search was location. As physical distance increased county, state, and national granularities, the personalized results grew. Queries also affected the personalization rate, with queries for local establishments receiving much more personalization than general queries.

Title: MapWatch: Detecting and monitoring international border personalization on online maps
"Be careful; Things can be worse than they appear" - Understanding biased algorithms and users' behavior around them in rating platforms
More of the same - On spotify radio
Summary: The study explores loop patterns in Spotify radio recommendations for four different types of sock puppets (likers, dislikers, skippers, and obedient listeners). They find that a radio starting with "Dancing Queen" repeats the song after about 50 tracks, and recommendations were similar across the four types of sock puppets.

Title: Quantifying search bias: Investigating sources of bias for political searches in social media
Summary: This audit evaluates and compares partisan biases on Google search and Twitter news search, accounting for input bias. They observe that Google highly depends on news media websites, Wikipedia, and social media for politically-related queries. Comparatively, they find that Twitter's search produces more democratic-leaning output, and Google exhibits higher stability over time.

Title: Analyzing the news coverage of personalized newspapers
Summary: Simulates readers who visit the "Recommendations for You" portion of the New York Times website and read random (n=3) or topically-focused stories (n=10); surfaces an apparent feedback loop that results in different personalized editions among users.

Title: Are We Exposed to the Same “News” in the News Feed?: An empirical analysis of filter bubbles as information similarity for Danish Facebook users
Summary: Finds that most users are generally exposed to similar information, both in terms of links and friend posts. Users with fewer friends and fewer page likes are more likely to be part of "echo chambers" with content not shared in other groups on the platform.

Title: Auditing partisan audience bias within Google search
Algorithm: Search engine results page - full page
Summary: An expansive study auditing partisan bias in all components of the Google search interface, including tweet cards, knowledge components, and "people also ask" components.

Title: Beyond the bubble: Assessing the diversity of political search results
Challenging Google Search filter bubbles in social and political information: Disconforming evidence from a digital methods case study
Summary: This study recruited a panel of 350 Dutch users and scraped their personalized results for 27 socio-political search queries. The results show a substantial dependence on mainstream media and regional government websites, and no substantial variation in search results due to personalization.

Title: Coding the News: The role of computer code in filtering and distributing news
Summary: Demonstrates through code auditing that news apps do not produce news, but rather play a gatekeeping role in ranking content. Thus, "non-journalist actors are defining conditions under which news is distributed."

Title: From ranking algorithms to ‘ranking cultures’: Investigating the modulation of visibility in YouTube search results
Summary: Using 44 days of scraped data for seven queries related to public controversies, this study exposes several characteristics of YouTube's search function. While some queries produced stable results, others were highly reactive to "attention cycles" and recent uploads. Also, while the platform depended on "newsy" content for many queries, it elevated visibility of "niche entrepreneurs" who used highly-specific "YouTube native" vernacular, thus showing that the underlying ranking mechanism relies on complex metrics beyond popularity, often to the disadvantage of established mainstream media producers.

Title: Investigating Ad Transparency Mechanisms in Social Media: A Case Study of Facebook's Explanations
Summary: This study seeks to determine whether Facebook's ad explanations are true transparency mechanisms. They found that information from the "why am I seeing this ad?" feature is often incomplete and sometimes misleading, and the ad preferences page (also explored in other audits) is often vague.

Title: Search bias quantification: investigating political bias in social media and web search
Summary: Presents expanded findings from the study above, focused on searches from the 2016 US Presidential primaries.

Title: Ad Delivery Algorithms: The Hidden Arbiters of Political Messaging
Summary: While other advertising audits focus on targeting, this study focuses on the delivery algorithms, which dictate the ads that users see in real-world use. They find that delivery algorithms limit exposure diversity in a number of ways.

Title: Auditing autocomplete: Suggestion networks and recursive algorithm interrogation
Summary: Using "recursive algorithmic interrogation" (RAI) to audit autocomplete on Google and Bing, this study finds consistent structure and linguistic patterns in queries, while also finding high churn rate and high dependency on social media content.

Title: Auditing the partisanship of Google search snippets
Algorithm: Search engine results page - text snippets
Summary: This paper finds that the summary "snippets" below links on Google search often amplify the partisanship relative to the page being linked.

Title: Bias misperceived: The role of partisanship and misinformation in YouTube comment moderation
Summary: Finds that extremist content, false content, and content posted after a video was fact-checked is more likely to be moderated, however it is unknown whether moderation was performed by an algorithm, a human moderator, or YouTube users.

Title: Comparing Platform “Ranking Cultures” Across Languages: The Case of Islam on YouTube in Scandinavia
Summary: Collecting YouTube search results for queries related to Islam, this study analyzes how the search algorithm presents videos that are critical of Islam (such as videoblogs news reports) alongside other videos (such as sermons and satire). Prominence varies between three languages: Swedish, Danish, and Norwegian. They also find that the algorithm sometimes "propels content which have attracted minimal attention to the top end of searches," and that results were stable throughout a month of data collection.

Title: Dr. Google, what can you tell me about homeopathy? Comparative study of the top10 websites in the United States, United Kingdom, France, Mexico and Spain
Summary: This study focuses on medical queries related to homeopathy, comparing results between four languages and five countries. They found that news was the "most abundant" type of content in a sample of pages, and that ranking is fairly stable over time. The overall stance of results (favoring or opposing homeopathy) varied between countries.

Title: Opening Up the Black Box: Auditing Google’s Top Stories Algorithm
Search as news curator: The role of Google in shaping attention to news information
Old-Behavior:
Gatekeeping power
Content dependency
Parisan bias
Summary: This study scraped Google's "top stories" for 188 different queries related to "hard news" topics. The results show a high degree of source concentration, a slight exacerbation of ideological skew, a dependency on highly-recent stories. They also find that articles in the middle of the "top stories" carousel receive the highest boost in referral traffic.

Title: Search media and elections: A longitudinal investigation of political search results in the 2018 U.S. Elections
Summary: A longitudinal audit of "blue links" that appear in searches for political candidates, showing that results for incumbent candidates and election winners had significantly lower partisanship compared to challengers, open seat candidates, and election losers.

Title: You Can’t See What You Can’t See: Experimental Evidence for How Much Relevant Information May Be Missed Due to Google’s Web Search Personalisation
Summary: Focusing on public officials's use of search engines, this audit found that among 30 participants, personalization may remove up to 20% of results that participants deemed as relevant to their query.

Title: Auditing local news presence on Google News
Auditing News Curation Systems: A Case Study Examining Algorithmic and Editorial Logic in Apple News
Auditing radicalization pathways on YouTube
Measuring Misinformation in Video Search Platforms: An Audit Study on YouTube
Automated Experiments on Ad Privacy Settings
Summary: A large-scale experiment that used over 16,000 agents to simulate advertisements on various demographics of users. Male agents were more likely than female agents to see ads for high paying jobs, and agents with browsing history related to substance abuse were shown a different distribution of ads, but this trait was not shown in Google's Ad Settings.

Title: Studying ad targeting with digital methods: The case of spotify
Summary: Demonstrates methods for auditing advertising systems, and depicts the extent of tracking: during a 60-minute session on Spotify, the desktop app sent over 1,000 ad-related http requests.

Title: The Substantial Interdependence of Wikipedia and Google: A Case Study on the Relationship Between Peer Production Communities and Information Technologies
Algorithm: Search engine results page - full page
Summary: This audit reveals how Google search results depend on content from Wikipedia. It shows that click-through rates increases by about 80% when Google includes Wikipedia pages in search results.

Title: Unveiling and Quantifying Facebook Exploitation of Sensitive Personal Data for Advertising Purposes
Summary: This study focuses on sensitive attributes (such as religious beliefs and sexual orientation) that Facebook uses for targeted advertising. They find that Facebook labels 73% of users in the European Union with attributes considered sensitive by the GDPR. Further, they show that malicious actors could unveil the identity and sensitive attributes of these Facebook users at a very low cost.

Title: Measuring the Importance of User-Generated Content to Search Engines
Algorithm: Search engine results page - full page
Summary: A follow-up to McMahon et al., focusing on the frequency of Wikipedia links in Google search results

Title: Out With the Old and in With the New? An Empirical Comparison of Supervised Learning Algorithms to Predict Recidivism
The Accuracy of the Demographic Inferences Shown on Google's Ad Settings
Summary: Focuses on Google's ability to infer gender and age. Based on 501 participants, Google often does not infer these characteristics for users who are logged out, but inferences that are made are generally accurate.

Title: Auditing Offline Data Brokers via Facebook's Advertising Platform
Summary: Uses a survey to determine which targeting attributes are incorrect compared to user ground truth, finding that at least 40% of attributes from data brokers were not at all accurate.

Title: Better Practices in the Development and Validation of Recidivism Risk Assessments: The Minnesota Sex Offender Screening Tool–4
Quantity vs. Quality: Evaluating User Interest Profiles Using Ad Preference Managers
Summary: Using a similar approach to other advertising audits, collecting ground truth information via survey. Participants only rated 27% of the interests in their profiles as strongly relevant.

Title: The right to confront your accusers: Opening the black box of forensic DNA software
Summary: An audit of the Forensic Statistical Tool (FST) used for DNA analysis, this study shows how an allegedly "minor" change to removal criteria resulted in substantial data-dropping that skewed the algorithmic output toward inaccurate results. In particular, the change excluded more true contributors and included more non-contributors for the DNA samples analyzed.

Title: Facebook Ads Monitor: An Independent Auditing System for Political Ads on Facebook
